byline.original: By CAROL TAVRIS; Carol Tavris, a social psychologist, is co-author of ''The Longest War: Sex Differences in Perspective'' and author of the forthcoming ''Anatomy of Anger.''

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CINDERELLA COMPLEX Women's Hidden Fear of Independence. By Colette Dowling. 266 pp. New York: Summit Books. $12.95. COLETTE DOWLING has not had an easy time of it. After her divorce, she spent four difficult years establishing herself as a writer, caring for three children singlehanded and tending to a former husband who was often hospitalized for emotional illness. Then she met a man, retired to the countryside and discovered blissful domesticity. She nested. She cooked. She stopped working. She planted a garden. She slept late. She loved being taken care of. Within a few short months, she realized that she had forfeited her independence, ambition and self-respect in a headlong retreat into woman's traditional role. In ''The Cinderella Complex,'' Miss Dowling attempts to make sense of her own experience by elevating it into an entire italicized thesis: ''Personal, psychological dependency - the deep wish to be taken care of by others - is the chief force holding women down today. ... Like Cinderella, women today are still waiting for something external to transform their lives.'' Without considering what an impersonal, un-psychological dependency might be, Miss Dowling offers psychological studies, interviews with psychiatrists and the experiences of an unspecified number of women to support her view.

headline.main: CONNECTICUT ALLOWS MARIJUANA CIGARETTES AS MEDICINE

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. William A. O'Neill signed a bill today allowing doctors to prescribe marijuana cigarettes for patients suffering from glaucoma or the side-effects of cancer treatments. The General Assembly defeated a similar bill in 1980, when even Ella T. Grasso, then Governor, who suffered from prolonged nausea after radiation treatment for cancer, declined to support the idea. This spring, however, the House of Representatives unexpectedly passed the bill after Representative Robert C. Sorensen, Democrat of Meriden, told a hushed chamber he was undergoing chemotherapy and on some days faced pain so severe he could not stand erect.
